user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_get_timestamp:
```c
unsigned long long metal_get_timestamp(void)
{
	unsigned long long t = 0;
	struct timespec tp;
	int r;

	r = clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &tp);
	if (r == -1) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
		return t;
	}
	t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S);
	t += tp.tv_nsec;

	return t;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_get_timestamp:
#define NS_PER_S (1000*1000*1000)
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n"); expands to a call to _metal.common.log_handler(level, metal_fmt(fmt), ...). This call does not itself modify any function parameter variable. A violation would occur if the called function reassigns one of its parameter variables (for example: void log_handler(int level, const char *fmt) { level = 0; } or void log_handler(char *p) { p = some_other_pointer; } ), i.e. the function body assigns to its parameter identifiers (including reassigning pointer parameters themselves).
